Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A flexible design and modeling framework for computer experiments and beyond
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary objective of this proposal is to develop a flexible framework for design and modeling of large-scale simulations with broad applications to other areas of statistics. The investigator studies a multi-step method for fitting massive data from computer simulations that can simultaneously mitigate singularity and improve accuracy of interpolation. Theoretical bounds on numeric and nominal accuracy of this method will be derived. The investigator also proposes new designs inspired by Sudoku to efficiently pool data from multiple sources and employs sliced Latin hypercube designs to enhance stochastic optimization and cross-validation.


Large-scale simulations are widely used for studying complex phenomena in sciences and engineering. The trend of replacing physical experiments with simulations to save cost and time has accelerated recently. The proposed research draws impetus from computer simulations but applies broadly to other areas of statistics for modeling massive data and for borrowing information from multiple sources. Beyond statistics, the research will make significant contributions to discrete mathematics, computer science and high-performance computing. Dissemination through journal publications, industrial collaborations and release of open source software will result in broad adoption of the developed research to significantly improve the use of complex simulations in U.S. industries. The research will be of considerable added value to rigorous uncertainty quantification efforts by national laboratories to support national security. Training students from under-represented groups will be accomplished through a puzzle based learning approach. Graduate students will benefit through multidisciplinary training on the interface between statistics and optimization. Ph.D. students will be supervised by following the Wisconsin model of balancing statistical theory and practice, and obtain first-hand research experience they can draw on for their careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computer experiments, i.e., experiments via simulation or numerical codes, are widely used for studying complex phenomena in sciences and engineering. The trend of replacing physical experiments with computer experiments to save cost and time has accelerated recently. Design and analysis of computer experiments is a rapidly growing area in statistics and closely related to the emerging field of Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) in applied mathematics, statistics, and engineering. This project has developed a flexible framework for design and modeling of computer experiments with broad applications to other areas of statistics. It consists of three main tasks. Task 1 developed a theoretical framework for bounding statistical and numeric accuracy in a large-scale predictive model. This framework applies to fitting various types of Big Data engineering and the Internet. Data pooling, i.e., borrowing information from multiple sources, is now commonplace in many scientific investigations. Task 2 introduced innovative designs based on the popular game Sudoku to address the new issue of efficient data collection from multiple sources. Task 3 uses a new type of space-filling design, sliced Latin hypercube design, to enhance two commonly used procedures in statistics: stochastic optimization (i.e., optimization involving integrals) and cross-validation.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of the developed work lies in a novel set of statistical concepts that draw impetus from computer experiments but apply broadly to other areas of statistics. The theoretical underpinning of bounding statistical and numeric accuracy provides a new way to look at how to best fit massive data. Sudoku based space-filling designs leads to a new direction in design of experiments that draw inspirations from popular puzzles to construct new statistical designs. Sliced Latin hypercube designs efficiently solve various challenging stochastic optimization problems in statistics. Sliced cross-validation treks a new path of using experimental design ideas to reduce variability of the cross-validation technique and can have many applications in statistics and computer science for tuning parameter selection, bandwidth selection and many other problems.

 Broader Impacts: Dissemination through more than 20 journal publications and industrial collaborations result in broad adoption of the developed research to significantly improve the use of complex simulations in many U.S. industries.  Training students from under-represented groups is accomplished through a Sudoku Day on Mathematical and Statistical Issues of Sudoku for undergraduate minority students. The Sudoku day introduced a new Puzzle based learning approach to undergraduate minority students and made them aware of the integrative nature of mathematics and science. Statistics graduate students have benefited through multidisciplinary training on the interface between statistics and optimization. 10 Ph.D. students have been supervised by following the Wisconsin model of balancing statistical theory and practice, and obtained first-hand research experience they can draw on for their careers.
